channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: IMF Wants Zimbabwe’s Gold-Backed ZiG to Become Sole Currency
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said it would like to see the ZiG “fully becoming a national currency,” as it weighs whether to place Zimbabwe on a staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

item.title: Yum China Forms Death Cross After a Golden Cross in October
item.description: The 50-day moving average of Yum China Holdings Inc. shares fell below their 200-day moving average after forming a golden cross in October.
item.dc:creator: William Maloney

media:content.media:description: Customers at a Yum China Taco Bell restaurant in Xi'an, China.

item.title: US-China Trade Talks ‘Going Well’: Commerce Secretary Lutnick
item.description: As delegations from the US and China begin a second day of trade talks, US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said things are “going well” and expects discussions to go “all day today.” He spoke with Bloomberg’s Annmarie Hordern outside Lancaster House in London.

item.title: Germany’s SEFE Strikes 10-Year Deal for Gas From Azerbaijan
item.description: Germany’s state-owned SEFE signed a 10-year deal to buy gas from Azerbaijan’s Socar, a move that will help diversify supplies in Europe’s tight market.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya, Todd Gillespie, Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: Storage silos operated by the State Oil Company of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOCAR) in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Thursday, Nov. 14, 2024. Azerbaijan, host of this year’s COP29 climate summit, will continue to invest in increasing gas production in order to feed demand from Europe as its president said that its abundant fossil fuels were a “gift from God.”

item.title: Diageo Weighs Options for Stake in Indian Cricket Team
item.description: Diageo Plc is considering options for its ownership of the Indian Premier League cricket franchise Royal Challengers Bengaluru, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Anto Antony, Dinesh Nair, Baiju Kalesh

media:content.media:description: Members of the Royal Challengers Bengaluru huddle during the 2025 IPL Final match in Ahmedabad, India, on June 3. Photographer: Pankaj Nangia/Getty Images

item.title: Gold Steadies as US-China Trade Talks Cool Demand for Safety
item.description: Gold steadied as signs the US and China are willing to make concessions on a second day of trade talks in London eased demand for haven assets.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: One-ounce Canadian gold coins at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers arranged in London, UK, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Gold retreated on Thursday, after notching its latest record, after President Donald Trump triggered tumult on global markets with sweeping “reciprocal” tariffs. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Grab’s Big Convertible Bond Fuels Hopes About GoTo Deal
item.description: Grab Holdings Ltd. announced plans for a $1.25 billion sale of bonds convertible into stock, the biggest of its kind among Asian companies this year, fueling speculation it’s bulking up its warchest to take over rival Southeast Asian delivery-and-transport provider GoTo Group.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian, Eduard Gismatullin

media:content.media:description: A man walks past a Grab Holdings Inc. facility in Singapore, on Friday, Sept. 25, 2020. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is in talks to invest $3 billion in Southeast Asian ride-hailing giant Grab, according to people familiar with the matter. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s Company Bond Funds Lure Most Inflows in Over Two Years
item.description: India’s corporate bond funds received the highest inflows in over two years as aggressive cash injections by the central bank spurred investments by the nation’s lenders.
item.dc:creator: Divya Patil, Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Agnellis Hunt €2 Billion Deal in Europe or US After Ferrari Sale
item.description: Italy’s Agnelli family has earmarked around €2 billion ($2.3 billion) to invest in a US or European company, as it looks to redeploy proceeds from the partial sale of its Ferrari NV stake.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob, Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: Guido de Boer Source: Exor NV

item.title: TSMC May Revenue Jumps 40% on AI Chip Demand
item.description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. reported a 40% increase in revenue for May after companies stockpiled chips in response to mounting trade uncertainty. Matthew Bloxham of Bloomberg Intelligence has more on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: US Futures Hover as Trade Talks Enter Second Day: Markets Wrap
item.description: US stock futures hovered as a second day of talks between the Trump administration and China got underway, with investors staying cautious in the absence of meaningful progress in the two nations’ trade dispute.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren

item.title: Investors Bank on No-Frills Pakistan Budget to Keep Rally Alive
item.description: Investors in Pakistan are hoping Tuesday’s budget stays focused on slashing spending, boosting revenues, and reinforcing the government’s commitment to its International Monetary Fund loan program.
item.dc:creator: Malavika Kaur Makol, Kamran Haider

item.title: Oil Starts Summer on Borrowed Time as OPEC+ Fuels Surplus Threat
item.description: The oil market is racing toward a reckoning as a Saudi-led output surge only adds to expectations of a market that will be in surplus later this year. The crucial question is when?
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Yongchang Chin, Anthony Di Paola

item.title: Accenture CEO on Trade, AI & Political Tensions
item.description: Companies are having to navigate economic uncertainty and a shifting geopolitical landscape, that's according to Accenture CEO, Julie Sweet. The consulting and technology giant has been grappling with a pullback in customer spending and greater scrutiny of US government contracts under President Trump. Julie Sweet joined Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua for an interview on how companies like Accenture are able to strategize in a world of global economic uncertainty, investment across industries as well as the role of artificial intelligence. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Russia’s Crude Shipments Rebound With a Rare Delivery to Japan
item.description: Sanctioned tanker carries Sakhalin crude to Taiyo Oil’s Shikoku refinery
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.36 million barrels a day of crude in the four weeks to June 8 after a strong rebound in flows in the latest week.

item.title: Britain Loses 276,000 Jobs Since Reeves’ Tax-Raising Budget
item.description: UK employment plunged by the most in five years and wage growth slowed more than forecast, in the clearest sign yet that Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ budget was fueling a deterioration in the British jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Commuters climb the stairs to exit Liverpool Street railway station in London, UK.

item.title: Wary Wall Street Positioning Leaves Room for S&P 500 to Rally
item.description: Analysts at firms including Barclays Plc and JPMorgan Chase & Co. see further upside for US stocks, in part because they expect institutional investors to abandon their cautious stance and ramp up exposure to equities.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: Novo Climbs After FT Reports Activist Parvus Amassed Stake
item.description: Novo Nordisk A/S shares rose to the highest level in more than two months after a report that activist hedge fund Parvus Asset Management has built a stake as the Danish drugmaker struggles to keep its lead in the obesity market.
item.dc:creator: Madison Muller

media:content.media:description: Novo’s drugs Ozempic and Wegovy have become household names.

item.title: Oil Extends Gain as Traders Await Fresh US-China Trade Talks
item.description: Oil ticked higher, rising for a fourth straight session, as the market awaits the outcome of a second day of trade talks between the US and China.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Storage tanks at a Colonial Pipeline Inc. facility in Avenel, New Jersey, U.S., on Wednesday, May 12, 2021. Motorists across a broad swath of the U.S. East Coast and South are struggling to find gasoline and diesel as filling stations run dry amid the unprecedented pipeline disruption caused by a criminal hack. Photographer: Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg

item.title: IHG's Maalouf: Growth is Moving East
item.description: President Trump's policies are upending travel worldwide as the ongoing trade war, border crackdown as well as a ban on visitors from a dozen countries have all led to tens of thousands of canceled trips. With travellers now choosing alternate destinations, the US economy is expected to lose out on $12.5-billion this year. Elie Maalouf, chief executive of IHG Hotels and Resorts explains to Francine Lacqua what this means for the travel, tourism and hospitality industry on Bloomberg TV. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: UK’s FTSE 100 Surpasses March Record as Tariff Concerns Ease
item.description: The UK’s FTSE 100 index was set to close at a record high for the first time since March, recouping its tariff-induced slump thanks to an improving economic outlook and easing trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Msika

item.title: Namibia to Raise $122 Million to Refinance Eurobond Due October
item.description: Namibia plans to raise $122 million in the domestic market to refinance a portion of its $750 million eurobond due October and will use a sinking fund to retire the balance, its Finance Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Kaula Nhongo

media:content.media:description: A road leading to the port in Walvis Bay, Namibia.

item.title: From Visas to Jets, US and China Are Finding New Trade Leverage
item.description: Donald Trump brought many of the same grievances to his second trade war against China, but the economic battleground that’s emerged since then is making it harder to avoid a rupture this time around.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: Trump’s Pick to Run CFTC Touts His Career in Crypto to Lawmakers
item.description: Brian Quintenz, President Donald Trump’s pick to lead the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission, plans to tell lawmakers he is uniquely qualified to head the derivatives regulator as Congress considers giving it more authority over digital assets
item.dc:creator: Nicola M White

item.title: ECB Can Still Move Quickly to Adjust Rates, Villeroy Says
item.description: The European Central Bank could still move quickly to adjust interest rates even after an eighth successive cut “normalized” monetary policy, according to Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Stocks Drop Suddenly as Investors Await US Trade Talks
item.description: Chinese stocks slid suddenly on Tuesday before the second day of trade talks with the US, showing that investors remain on the edge as the world’s two largest economies seek to address some contentious issues.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Ngai, Lin Zhu

media:content.media:description: Photo by WANG ZHAO/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: WANG ZHAO/AFP

item.title: China Extends Probe Into European Pork in Reprieve for Farmers
item.description: China extended its probe into European pork for another six months, providing a temporary reprieve to farmers and producers who risk losing one of their major markets.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu

media:content.media:description: Pigs on a farm in Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Iron Ore Edges Lower With Recovery Hopes Pinned on Trade Talks
item.description: Iron ore fell for a second day, as traders watched for any progress from US-China trade talks and potential stimulus from Beijing that could reignite demand for the steelmaking staple.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell

item.title: Horizons Middle East & Africa 06/10/2025
item.description: Horizons Middle East & Africa is your daily spotlight on one of the world's fastest-growing regions. Live from Dubai, we bring you the latest global markets and analysis, plus news-making interviews, with a special focus on MEA. All that and more, as you head to the office in the Gulf, pause for lunch in Hong Kong, or start your day in London or Johannesburg. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Zambia Sees Economic Growth Surging to Highest Since 2021
item.description: Zambia’s economy will expand at least 6% this year as Africa’s second-largest copper producer reaps the benefit of improved rainfall and higher metal production, the finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Copper plates on wagons ready for shipping at a refinery in Mufulira, Zambia.
